Pre-Game Insights: New India vice-captain Shubman Gill is looking to address his T20I batting performances heading into the next cycle.
Gill’s numbers in the T20Is – 505 runs from 19 games at an average of 29.7 and a strike rate of 139.5 – are yet to meet his own lofty standards.

The 24-year-old, fresh after being named the team's vice-captain, is hoping to transfer his form in ODIs – he has 2271 runs from 44 matches at an average of 61.37 and a strike-rate of 103.46 – to the shortest format of the game.
Gill said at the pre-match press conference ahead of the first T20I against Sri Lanka that he is not satisfied with his performances in T20Is till the T20 World Cup 2024.
Gill is ready to address these concerns in the upcoming cycle, with about 30-40 T20Is, and hopes to improve on his performance as a player.
Gill expressed his belief that the challenge of vice-captaincy wouldn't hinder his on-field performance.
Gill was confident of working well with India’s new T20I captain Suryakumar Yadav, noting their similar communication and understanding.
With the retirements of Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma from T20Is, Gill is set to open with Yashasvi Jaiswal, signalling a new era.
Gill mentioned that he and Jaiswal enjoy batting together, with their shots complementing each other and a good understanding and communication.
India's tour of Sri Lanka begins with a T20I on 27 July, 2024.
